Your article about Governors Island (''Sleeping Beauty,'' Feb. 5) brought back many memories, as did the 1955 photo of the island, looking like a giant potholder. That was the year that I began a 21-month Army stint there, at what was then First Army Headquarters.

Governors Island was considered the most enviable place for an Army draftee from New York to spend his days in uniform. Married enlisted men were even allowed to live off-base, taking the ferry back and forth on weekdays. I wound up there because I had worked as a legal stenographer while attending City College at night, and the island was the location of court-martial trials for offenses ranging from desertion to collaborating with the enemy (North Korea at that time).

Enviable assignment or not, there was a no-nonsense military aspect to the place. There were spit-and-polish formations and parades and details like K.P. (kitchen police) and prison guard. Castle Williams, the stockade for prisoners awaiting trial, remains a baleful presence to this day, and I often wonder where the lives of those whose testimony I took at trials have taken them.
